awd_abstract_narration:
Many coastal areas are undergoing tremendous morphological change, resulting in deterioration of habitats and livelihoods, and altering the exchanges between land and ocean. For example, near Katama Bay, Martha's Vineyard, Massachussetts, sediment transport and morphological evolution is affecting water quality, oyster farms, tourism, and homes and structures. Waves from Hurricanes Irene and Sandy combined with strong currents caused 2.5 meter of erosion and accretion near Katama Inlet. In addition, the inlet is migrating hundreds of meters per year, and eventually will close until a storm again breaches the barrier beach separating the bay from the ocean. This project will use a combination of existing field observations and numerical model simulations to determine the causes of such morphological evolution. By investigating the effects of tides, waves, and currents on the dynamic coast of Martha's Vineyard, this research project will lead to an improved understanding of the processes driving shoreline evolution on ocean beaches and in or near inlets. The team will collaborate with U.S. Geological Survey scientists on model development for addressing a range of future scenarios and will work with local stake holders and managers to provide simulations and information about possible changes to the shoreline in response to different forcing and management choices, as well as to help plan for inlet closings and the associated changes in water quality and access. The project will also produce video lessons for high school students on relevant STEM topics.

The study will address the hypotheses that: (i) migration of the inlet is owing to a combination of large nor'easters and hurricanes, more frequent, but more moderate wave events, and strong tidal flows, (ii) the timing of storms relative to flood and ebb flows and the storm duration are important to the morphological evolution, (iii) accretion inside the bay is caused by sand carried alongshore and subsequently transported into the inlet during flood flows, and (iv) closure of the inlet occurs when a large storm coincides with one or more spring flood tides, carrying sand into the inlet. The large morphological signal combined with existing observations of waves, currents, and the changing bathymetry make this site an ideal location to address hypotheses for shoreline morphological evolution, to calibrate, test, and improve numerical models that simulate the observed evolution, and to use models to predict future changes for different scenarios. Although this study will focus on the Martha's Vineyard site where there is substantial observational data and model infrastructure, the results will be applicable to a wide range of shoreline systems, with or without inlets. The dominant processes may differ from site to site, but the fundamental physics incorporated in the model are similar.

por.por_cntn:
We investigated the ~2 km migration of Katama Inlet on the southern shore of Martha?s Vineyard, MA from when it breached (200&) until it closed (2015) to address the hypotheses migration of the inlet is owing to a combination of large nor?easters and hurricanes, more frequent, but more moderate wave events, and strong tidal flows.

We discovered that waves crossing strong tidal currents (3 m/s) on the inner continental shelf are refracted as much as 35-degrees back and forth (70-degrees total) with the tide. Thus, even for the same offshore wave conditions, the directions of currents and sediment transport near the shoreline can change every tidal cycle.

We also learned that sediment motion is affected by the flow fields near curving coastlines (e.g., headlands, corners), in this case the shape of the southeast corner of Chappaquiddick Island. There can be an area of quiescent water near these coastal features. As the curvature of the coast changes owing to erosion and accretion, the size and location of the zone of quiescent water where strong tidal flows separate from the coast also change, affecting the amount of sediment motion near the shoreline.  Thus, consideration of larger scale features and inner shelf currents may be important to simulating nearby shoreline morphological evolution.

An additional outcome is that tidal currents tend to scour (erode) the inlet channel, whereas waves tend to deposit sand within the channel area. At this location, the predominant wave direction is from the southwest, thus driving sediment toward the east, resulting in the ~2 km migration of Katama Inlet  between 2007 when it was breached until 2015 when it closed after reaching Chappaquiddick Island.

Numerical simulations and observations suggest that short, intense storms (e.g., hurricanes) move more sediment than less intense, longer storms (e.g., nor?easters) with the same overall integrated energy. The increased morphological change caused by hurricanes is relatively small, and usually there are more nor?easters than hurricanes in a year. Thus, although hurricanes cause large changes to the nearshore morphology, over a year more change is caused by the more numerous (usually) nor?easters.

The dissertations of 2 MIT-WHOI Joint program doctoral students (Mara Orescanin, now an assistant professor at the Naval Postgraduate School and Julia Hopkins, now a post-doc at TU Delft, who will start as an assistant professor at Northeastern University next year) were based on this project, as was the post-doctoral research of Laura Slivinski (now at NCAR in Colorado). Two PhD dissertations, 1 MS Engr (MIT), 4 undergraduate senior research projects, 16 presentations at national and international meetings, and 13 published journal papers (11 with student or post-doc first authors) were supported by this project.

We also interacted with the local community, and provided the harbormaster, boating organizations, and shell-fishermen with updated bathymetric maps to help with operations and with management decisions, and we presented results at meetings for local coastal managers, including SeaGrant officers, and the Massachusetts Trustees of Reservations, as well as at meetings of local citizens on Chappaquiddick Is., Martha?s Vineyard, and Cape Cod.
